description:
This adds show() and _repr_png methods to Scene that can be used within the Jupyter notebook. See this notebook for an example: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/2444792f889c2f7d36b1

Update: The image background has been made black and the show() method now takes an optional sigma_clip argument, like sc.save(). New notebook: https://gist.github.com/2f7d7fd5b3ae270375b5

Update 2: No longer defining _repr_png() dynamically. New notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/f47f7219fcb947e1aae5
title: [Experimental] show() method for Scene objects

content.raw: cool! I'm glad this was trivial to implement.
content.html: cool! I'm glad this was trivial to implement.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite_dev/769/

content.html: ROCK ON. Thanks, Andrew Myers !

content.raw: I wonder if we should do something to the alpha to make the background black?
content.html: I wonder if we should do something to the alpha to make the background black?

content.raw: We could do this using the add_background_color() method of ImageArray. Right now, the background is transparent, and how that is displayed is controlled by some (matplotlib? Ipython?) default. I don't have a strong opinion was to which behavior is better.
content.html: We could do this using the add_background_color() method of ImageArray. Right now, the background is transparent, and how that is displayed is controlled by some (matplotlib? Ipython?) default. I don't have a strong opinion was to which behavior is better.

content.raw: I'm fine with having a black background if no background has been chosen by the user (if it's possible to detect that, of course).
content.html: I'm fine with having a black background if no background has been chosen by the user (if it's possible to detect that, of course).

content.raw: I agree that a black background makes a good default when none has been specified.  Plus, then it matches the defaults of `save()`.  I think having `show()` and `save()` return identical results, or people may become confused.
content.html: I agree that a black background makes a good default when none has been specified. Plus, then it matches the defaults of save(). I think having show() and save() return identical results, or people may become confused.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite_dev/773/

So scene doesn't have a `_repr_png_` until you explicitly call show? I'm not really a fan of that, you should be able to just have the repr evaluated by having the scene object be the last statement in a code cell in a notebook.

I also think having `sigma_clip` be a property of the scene object more closely follows the design philosphy of the rest of the VR interface.
content.html:
So scene doesn't have a _repr_png_ until you explicitly call show? I'm not really a fan of that, you should be able to just have the repr evaluated by having the scene object be the last statement in a code cell in a notebook.

I also think having sigma_clip be a property of the scene object more closely follows the design philosphy of the rest of the VR interface.

content.raw: Here's a compromise: don't dynamically define `_repr_png_` in show, instead save the sigma_clip value in a private instance variable named _sigma_clip. I'd still prefer to remove it as a keyword argument of save and show, but I seem to be in the minority here.
content.html: Here's a compromise: don't dynamically define _repr_png_ in show, instead save the sigma_clip value in a private instance variable named _sigma_clip. I'd still prefer to remove it as a keyword argument of save and show, but I seem to be in the minority here.

content.raw:
What is an instance of using `__repr_png__()` when you haven't called `show()`.  I thought that `show()` was meant to be our primary method for displaying a figure in ipython notebooks?  

We've discussed that `sigma_clip` modifies the actual resulting data to not reflect the actual values returned by the `render()` function.  So why would we have its value just set for a `Scene` class?  What about as we start rotating views, or updating to a new `ds` in a `TimeSeries` object--do we always want to use the same `sigma_clip` value?  If so, then perhaps we should consider setting it as a class attribute, but my gut is not to do that.
content.html:
What is an instance of using __repr_png__() when you haven't called show(). I thought that show() was meant to be our primary method for displaying a figure in ipython notebooks?

We've discussed that sigma_clip modifies the actual resulting data to not reflect the actual values returned by the render() function. So why would we have its value just set for a Scene class? What about as we start rotating views, or updating to a new ds in a TimeSeries object--do we always want to use the same sigma_clip value? If so, then perhaps we should consider setting it as a class attribute, but my gut is not to do that.

content.raw:
Here's a basic example that shows how PlotWindow's `_repr_html_` gets invoked without actually being called by a user

https://gist.github.com/4e7c97882a0f26c39302

The same thing would happen if you referenced a scene object or a function returned it at the end of a code cell.

I strongly think `_repr_png_` should be defined by default and not defined dynamically as is done in this PR.
content.html:
Here's a basic example that shows how PlotWindow's _repr_html_ gets invoked without actually being called by a user

https://gist.github.com/4e7c97882a0f26c39302

The same thing would happen if you referenced a scene object or a function returned it at the end of a code cell.

I strongly think _repr_png_ should be defined by default and not defined dynamically as is done in this PR.

content.raw:
So I'm assuming that `__repr__` gets overridden by the `__repr_png__` method in an ipython notebook?  Is there a way of not having this so?  I can see there being utility in seeing the current structure of the `Scene` object visualized using the `__repr__` method.  I'd think *that* would be the ideal when someone just displays it with `print Scene`.

In order to have `__repr_png__` defined by default,  we have to have a `sigma_clip` defined as an attribute or property of the `Scene`, and I still haven't seen a good justification for this on how it would affect the things I described in the previous post.
content.html:
So I'm assuming that __repr__ gets overridden by the __repr_png__ method in an ipython notebook? Is there a way of not having this so? I can see there being utility in seeing the current structure of the Scene object visualized using the __repr__ method. I'd think that would be the ideal when someone just displays it with print Scene.

In order to have __repr_png__ defined by default, we have to have a sigma_clip defined as an attribute or property of the Scene, and I still haven't seen a good justification for this on how it would affect the things I described in the previous post.

content.raw:
IPython `_repr_*_` methods don't get invoked on print, only if they're the last value in a code cell.

Right now I'm more concerned that `_repr_png_` is getting dynamically defined, I really don't like that.
content.html:
IPython _repr_*_ methods don't get invoked on print, only if they're the last value in a code cell.

Right now I'm more concerned that _repr_png_ is getting dynamically defined, I really don't like that.

content.raw: then how about having a `__repr_png__` that is statically defined without the `sigma_clip` applied.  But then if you do call `show()` then it defines it dynamically as @atmyers has done in this PR?
content.html: then how about having a __repr_png__ that is statically defined without the sigma_clip applied. But then if you do call show() then it defines it dynamically as Andrew Myers has done in this PR?

content.raw: Looks good.  Thanks for all of your hard work on this, @atmyers !
content.html: Looks good. Thanks for all of your hard work on this, Andrew Myers !
